bestBHT.bht: The 'churches of the Gentiles' were thankful to Aquila and Priscilla for rescuing the Apostle Paul from danger and risking their lives in the process. They held worship assemblies in their home, which exemplified their dedication to serving the Lord. The Gentile churches recognized their deep obligation to them for saving the life of the apostle who had founded their churches. Aquila and Priscilla were dear not only to Paul but also to all the Gentiles, who esteemed them for their selfless act of heroism.

Henry Alford: The 'churches of the Gentiles' had reason to be thankful to them, for having rescued the Apostle of the Gentiles from danger.
It seems to have been the practice of Aquila and... to hold assemblies for worship in their houses, which were saluted, and sent salutations as one body in the Lord.

The answer was, 'Where each one can and will. You believe; no doubt, that we all meet together in one place; but it is not so, for the God of the Christians is not shut up in a room, but, being invisible, He fills both heaven and earth, and is honored everywhere by the faithful.'
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: who did for my life lay down"
they were at least the most endeared to our apostle
Albert Barnes: Who have for my life - In order to save my life.

Laid down their own necks - To 'lay down the neck' is to lay the head on a block to be cut off with the axe; or to bow down the head as when the neck was exposed to be cut off by the sword of the executioner.

All the churches of the Gentiles - All the churches that had been founded by the apostles. They 'felt' their deep obligation to them for having saved the life of him who had been their founder, and who was their spiritual father.
Marvin Vincent: Who [οιτινες]. The double relative, with an explanatory force: seeing that they.
Laid down their own necks [τον εαυτων τραχηλον υπεθηκαν]. Laid down is, literally, placed under (the axe).
Whether the expression is literal or figurative, or if literal, when the incident occurred, cannot be determined.
John Calvin: And deservedly dear and precious to all the Gentiles was the life of such a man, as it was an incomparable treasure: it was therefore no wonder that all the Churches of the Gentiles thought themselves to be under obligations to his preservers." (472)
What he adds respecting the Church in their house is worthy of being observed; for he could not have more splendidly adorned their household than by giving it the title of a Church." (473)
They had no churches or temples to meet in; private houses were their churches." (473)
Philip Schaff: Who for (‘in behalf of,’ not, ‘instead of’) my life laid down, etc. Lit., ‘laid under,’ used of submitting to execution."
That they underwent peril of their life for the sake of Paul is clearly meant; whether at Ephesus or Corinth is uncertain, since in both places Paul had been exposed to violence."
The Gentile churches owed gratitude for what was done in behalf of the Apostle to the Gentiles.
Archibald T. Robertson: Certainly Paul felt deep obligation toward them.
Not I alone. The Gentile churches also.
John Gill: Who for my life laid down their necks...they risked their own lives for the apostle's..."
I give thanks, but all the churches of the Gentiles...expresses his sense of gratitude for, and which all the Gentile churches were under obligations to do likewise...
They had a common share in his labours and usefulness, he was the apostle of them all; and also for their help and assistance in carrying on the work of the Lord in all the churches of the Gentiles.
John Wesley: Who have for my life, as it were, laid down their own necks - That is, exposed themselves to the utmost danger.
But likewise all the churches of the gentiles — Even that at Rome, for preserving so valuable a life.

bhtAttempts.bht: The verse speaks of Aquila and Priscilla, who risked their lives and laid down their own necks for the Apostle Paul. They rescued him from danger and held assemblies for worship in their home. The Gentile churches felt grateful and indebted to them for saving Paul's life, as he was their founder and spiritual father. They expressed their deep obligation to Aquila and Priscilla, recognizing that they played a significant role in the spread of the Gospel among the Gentiles. The churches of the Gentiles esteemed Aquila and Priscilla, for they were not only dear to Paul but also to all the Gentiles. Those who risked their lives for the Apostle Paul were regarded as heroes and deserving of utmost gratitude.

Aquila and Priscilla risked their lives and laid down their own necks to save Paul. They held worship assemblies in their home, and the Gentile churches were thankful to them for preserving Paul's life. The churches recognized their deep obligation to Aquila and Priscilla, acknowledging their significant role in spreading the Gospel. They were dear not only to Paul, but also to all the Gentiles, who esteemed them for their selfless act of heroism.

The 'churches of the Gentiles' owed their gratitude to Aquila and Priscilla for rescuing the Apostle Paul from danger and risking their own lives in the process. The Gentile churches recognized the deep obligation they had toward Aquila and Priscilla for saving the life of the apostle who had founded their churches. They held worship assemblies in their home, which further exemplified their dedication to serving the Lord. Their selfless act of heroism earned them the admiration and appreciation not only from Paul but also from all the Gentile churches.

The 'churches of the Gentiles' were thankful to Aquila and Priscilla for rescuing the Apostle Paul from danger and risking their lives in the process. They held worship assemblies in their home, which exemplified their dedication to serving the Lord. The Gentile churches recognized their deep obligation to them for saving the life of the apostle who had founded their churches. Aquila and Priscilla were dear not only to Paul but also to all the Gentiles, who esteemed them for their selfless act of heroism.

The 'churches of the Gentiles' expressed gratitude to Aquila and Priscilla for rescuing the Apostle Paul from danger and risking their lives. They held worship assemblies in their home, demonstrating their dedication to the Lord. The Gentile churches felt deeply indebted to them for saving the life of the apostle, who established their churches. Aquila and Priscilla were esteemed not only by Paul but also by all the Gentile churches for their courageous sacrifice.
